title: 108_hr822
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wild Sky Wilderness Act of 2003" and includes findings and a statement of policy. Congress finds that Americans value diverse wilderness ecosystems and wildlife on Federal lands, feeling a moral responsibility to protect this heritage for future generations. The benefits of wilderness areas are maximized when they are varied in topography, ecosystems, and recreational opportunities. Large blocks of wildlands with diverse ecosystems are essential for preserving these values. Certain wildlands in the Skykomish River valley of Washington represent the original forested landscape with diverse ecosystems, including high alpine meadows, rugged peaks, and old-growth forests with large trees. These areas harbor a variety of wildlife and fish species from the 19th century. The Skykomish River valley in Washington is home to diverse ecosystems and wildlife, including mountain goats, bald eagles, black bear, and endangered species like northern spotted owls and wild salmon. This wilderness area is accessible year-round for hikers, hunters, anglers, and educational groups who appreciate clean water, clean air, and pristine scenery. Congress declares it a policy to protect and serve the diverse wilderness in the United States. The policy of the United States is to grant wilderness protection to lower elevation wildlands in the Skykomish River valley of Washington and protect additional lands adjacent to the Henry M. Jackson Wilderness. This is in tribute to the ecologically enlightened vision of a former Senator from Washington. The policy of the United States is to grant wilderness protection to lower elevation wildlands in the Skykomish River valley of Washington and protect additional lands adjacent to the Henry M. Jackson Wilderness. This is in tribute to the ecologically enlightened vision of a former Senator from Washington. Addition to National Wilderness Preservation System, State of Washington. The Wild Sky Wilderness in Washington, totaling 106,000 acres, is designated as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide maps and legal descriptions to relevant committees. The Wild Sky Wilderness in Washington, totaling 106,000 acres, is designated as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The Secretary of Agriculture will manage it in accordance with the Wilderness Act and may correct errors in legal descriptions. The area can be managed as part of a larger complex of wilderness areas for administrative efficiencies. New trails may be established. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a trail plan for National Forest System lands, including hiking and equestrian trails within the Wild Sky Wilderness and adjacent areas. Within two years, a report on the implementation of the trail plan, including priority trails for development, will be submitted to Congress. The Wild Sky Wilderness allows for the construction and maintenance of a repeater site for improved communication. The operation of the Evergreen Mountain Lookout is also permitted. Access to private inholdings is allowed in accordance with specified regulations. The Wild Sky Wilderness allows for access to private inholdings and floatplane access on Lake Isabel. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to acquire lands in the wilderness through purchase, donation, or exchange. The Secretary of Agriculture can acquire lands in the Wild Sky Wilderness through purchase, donation, or exchange, with priority given to Priority Acquisition Lands. Valuation of private lands should not consider restrictions on access or use. The boundaries of the Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forests and the Wild Sky Wilderness will be adjusted as needed for land acquisitions or exchanges. SEC. 4. LAND EXCHANGES, CHELAN COUNTY PUBLIC UTILITY DISTRICT, WASHINGTON. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a land exchange with the Chelan County Public Utility District in Washington, exchanging lands as depicted on a specific map. If the Utility District offers approximately 371.8 acres of lands within 90 days, the Secretary will accept them if the title is acceptable and there are no hazardous materials. Upon acceptance, the Secretary will convey easements. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey a permanent easement to the Chelan County Public Utility District for maintaining a snowtel site on Federal land in the Wenatchee National Forest in Washington. The easement will be extinguished if the Utility District no longer needs to monitor snowpack for hydroelectric projects in the area. If the Utility District no longer needs to monitor snowpack, the easement will be extinguished and rights will revert to the United States.
